Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Christopher Reed of the Department of Chemistry at the University of California, Riverside will explore the extremes of cation chemistry by utilizing the most stable, least basic, least coordinating anion - the perfluorinated carborane anion. The conjugate acid of this anion may be the world's strongest acid. It should be a strong enough acid to add H+ to some of the most weakly basic molecules, ones that have not been protonated before (e.g. Xe). The acid will also be explored as a novel catalyst for acid-catalyzed reactions such the room temperature cracking of hydrocarbons and the decomposition of halocarbons and freons. There are potential uses in the remediation of halocarbon chemical waste, converting it into useful hydrocarbons fuels.

The broader impacts of this research include the possibility that new knowledge about cations, acidity and inert anions will impact commercially important areas such as petroleum reforming, polymerization catalysis, battery technology and fuel cell technology. The grant is primarily a vehicle for student training in research. UC Riverside has a high population of students from traditionally under-represented groups (e.g. Hispanics) so this project provides excellent opportunities for involving them in frontline chemical research and attracting them to careers in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Protons are hydrogen atoms that have lost an electron and therfore, have a positive charge. Protons are  particles that facilitate life and also are key species in many processes of industrial importance, such as petroleum refining and pharmaceutical synthesis. Compounds that donate protons to other molecules are called Bronstead acids. Acids that are stronger than 100% purer sulfuric acid are named super acids. Traditionally super acids are formed in highly corrosive mixtures of liquids with high antimony content. The presence of this antimony limits the ability of the acid to transfer its proton to other molecules of interest. This work has lead to the development of single component solid acids that are much stronger than traditional super acid mixtures and at the same time are non-corrosive. In fact, we have reported the strongest acid that exists H(HCB11F11). The super acidity of this molecule is achieved by pairing the positively charged proton with a fluorinated cluster compound called a carborane anion. This acid and its relatives have lead to the discovery of many hitherto unknown protonated species, such as thermally stable carbocations and protonated CO2. This acid is so strong that it will protonate hydrocarbons to liberate dihydrogen or form protonated aromatics. The fundamental knowledge gained here will redifine the way the chemistry of protons is taught in school. In addition, this work has provided a training ground for a variety of students who will emerge as the next generation of scientific leaders in the U.S.
